content.title: Hypophosphatemia
content.summary: Serum phosphorus <2.5 mg/dL caused by decreased intake, transcellular shifts, or renal losses, presenting with muscle weakness, respiratory failure, and cardiac dysfunction in severe cases
key_points: Defined as serum phosphorus <2.5 mg/dL (severe <1.0 mg/dL)
Three mechanisms: decreased intake/absorption, transcellular shift, renal losses
Refeeding syndrome is classic cause of severe hypophosphatemia
Respiratory muscle weakness can cause ventilator dependence
Severe cases require IV phosphate replacement
Critical for ATP production and cellular energy metabolism
Commonly seen in alcoholics, DKA recovery, and hospitalized patients

statement.text: Hypophosphatemia is defined as serum phosphorus below 2.5 mg/dL, with severe hypophosphatemia below 1.0 mg/dL. It occurs through three mechanisms: decreased intake or intestinal absorption, transcellular shift (insulin, refeeding, respiratory alkalosis), or increased renal excretion (hyperparathyroidism, Fanconi syndrome). Clinical manifestations reflect phosphorus's critical role in ATP synthesis and include muscle weakness, respiratory failure, cardiac dysfunction, and neurological symptoms.
statement.formal: Hypophosphatemia = Serum PO4 <2.5 mg/dL = ↓Intake + ↓Absorption OR Transcellular shift OR ↑Renal losses

explanation.intuition: Phosphorus is the 'P' in ATP—the energy currency of all cells. When phosphorus drops severely, cells cannot make enough ATP, and energy-dependent functions fail. Muscles weaken (including the diaphragm), the heart pumps poorly, and red blood cells become fragile. The classic scenario is refeeding a malnourished patient—insulin drives phosphorus into cells, causing sudden severe depletion.
explanation.key_insight: The timing and mechanism matter: acute hypophosphatemia (transcellular shift) causes symptoms at higher levels than chronic depletion because there's no time for compensation. Refeeding syndrome is dangerous precisely because it combines acute shift with underlying depletion in malnourished patients.
explanation.technical_details: Phosphorus exists as inorganic phosphate (measured in serum) and organic phosphate (ATP, 2,3-DPG, phospholipids). Serum levels represent <1% of total body phosphorus; most is in bone (85%) and intracellular (14%). Renal handling: freely filtered, 80-90% reabsorbed in proximal tubule via NaPi-IIa/c transporters regulated by PTH, FGF23, and dietary phosphorus.

definitions_glossary.hypophosphatemia: Serum phosphorus concentration below the normal range of 2.5-4.5 mg/dL
definitions_glossary.severe_hypophosphatemia: Serum phosphorus <1.0 mg/dL, associated with symptomatic disease
definitions_glossary.refeeding_syndrome: Metabolic derangements occurring when nutrition is reintroduced to malnourished patients, characterized by hypophosphatemia
definitions_glossary.phosphorus: Essential mineral required for ATP synthesis, bone mineralization, and cell membrane integrity
definitions_glossary.transcellular_shift: Movement of electrolytes between extracellular and intracellular compartments
definitions_glossary.fanconi_syndrome: Proximal tubular dysfunction causing renal wasting of phosphorus, glucose, amino acids, and bicarbonate
definitions_glossary.parathyroid_hormone: Hormone that increases renal phosphorus excretion by downregulating proximal tubule reabsorption
definitions_glossary.fgf23: Fibroblast growth factor 23—phosphaturic hormone secreted by osteocytes
definitions_glossary.atp: Adenosine triphosphate—primary cellular energy molecule requiring phosphorus
definitions_glossary.two_three_dpg: 2,3-diphosphoglycerate—regulates hemoglobin oxygen affinity; depleted in hypophosphatemia
definitions_glossary.rhabdomyolysis: Muscle breakdown that can result from severe hypophosphatemia due to ATP depletion
definitions_glossary.phosphate_binders: Medications that bind dietary phosphorus in the gut (used in hyperphosphatemia, not hypophosphatemia)

pathophysiology.mechanism: Phosphorus is essential for ATP synthesis, 2,3-DPG production (oxygen delivery), cell membrane integrity, and bone mineralization. Depletion impairs energy-dependent cellular processes. In muscles, ATP depletion causes weakness and rhabdomyolysis. In red blood cells, low 2,3-DPG increases hemoglobin-oxygen affinity, impairing oxygen delivery to tissues. Cardiac myocytes lose contractility, and neurological dysfunction occurs due to impaired neurotransmission.
etiological_categories: Decreased intake/absorption: malnutrition, alcoholism, phosphate binders, malabsorption, vitamin D deficiency
Transcellular shift: insulin (DKA treatment, refeeding), respiratory alkalosis, hungry bone syndrome
Renal losses: hyperparathyroidism, Fanconi syndrome, post-transplant, diuretics, X-linked hypophosphatemia

organ_system_effects.respiratory: Diaphragm weakness, ventilator dependence, weaning failure

diagnostic_approach: Low urinary phosphorus → decreased intake or transcellular shift
High urinary phosphorus → renal wasting (check PTH, vitamin D, FGF23)

oral_replacement.indication: Mild to moderate hypophosphatemia, asymptomatic patients
oral_replacement.preparations: Sodium/potassium phosphate (Neutra-Phos, K-Phos), milk (1 mg phosphorus/mL)

iv_replacement.indication: Severe hypophosphatemia (<1.0 mg/dL), symptomatic patients, unable to take PO
iv_replacement.dose: 0.08-0.32 mmol/kg over 6 hours; 15-30 mmol for most adults
iv_replacement.monitoring: Recheck phosphorus every 6 hours, monitor calcium (risk of precipitation)
iv_replacement.precautions: Avoid in hypercalcemia, reduce dose in renal impairment

underlying_cause.refeeding: Slow reintroduction of nutrition, prophylactic phosphorus supplementation
underlying_cause.dka: Expect phosphorus to drop as insulin is given; replace when <1.5 mg/dL
underlying_cause.alcoholism: Aggressive repletion; address vitamin D deficiency, magnesium

definition.@value: Electrolyte disorder characterized by serum phosphorus below 2.5 mg/dL, caused by decreased intake, transcellular shifts, or renal losses

skos.scopeNote: Covers etiology, clinical manifestations, diagnostic evaluation, and treatment including refeeding syndrome
skos.example: A 45-year-old alcoholic admitted with pneumonia, serum phosphorus 0.8 mg/dL on day 3 after starting enteral nutrition, with progressive respiratory failure requiring intubation

learning_objectives: Classify hypophosphatemia by severity and clinical significance
Differentiate etiologies using urinary phosphorus excretion
Recognize clinical manifestations of severe hypophosphatemia
Identify patients at risk for refeeding syndrome
Prescribe appropriate oral and IV phosphorus replacement
clinical_pearls: Refeeding syndrome: start feeding slowly, give thiamine first, supplement phosphorus prophylactically
DKA: serum phosphorus may be normal on admission but drops with insulin; monitor closely
Respiratory failure unresponsive to ventilator settings? Check phosphorus
Alcoholics are at high risk due to poor intake + transcellular shifts
Severe hypophosphatemia can cause hemolysis—check hemoglobin
Correct hypomagnesemia—magnesium deficiency impairs phosphorus repletion

board_yield.nephrology_boards: High - renal wasting, Fanconi syndrome, FGF23 disorders

common_misconceptions: High serum phosphorus on admission to DKA means total body phosphorus is adequate (false—shift from cells)
Oral replacement is always sufficient (false—severe cases need IV)
Phosphorus repletion can be given rapidly like potassium (caution—risk of hypocalcemia, precipitation)

skos:related.skos:note: Often coexists, risk with IV phosphorus
